1556.53.text: and what the role is space station has in Mars

1560.10.text: and in moon and other activities,

1562.23.text: and you can see space station playing a critical role

1565.86.text: So, as we are addressing the human health problems

1568.50.text: needed for adaptation for long-duration space flight,

1572.30.text: you can see how this space station

1575.46.text: and that first real step in exploration.

1577.36.text: So, as we push human presence into the solar system

1580.23.text: and we do this thing we call pioneering,

1582.56.text: space station is going to play that pivotal role.

1584.89.text: So, it's neat to see station.

1587.20.text: It's neat to see it in this venue

1589.26.text: where we get a chance to see not only the typical NASA research,

1592.86.text: we get to see the commercial activity,

1594.63.text: and we get to see how station fits in the exploration role

1598.46.text: -Finally, while it may not have had

1600.26.text: the biggest impact on scientific research this year,

1606.76.text: certainly made a big splash on the Internet.

1609.66.text: Earlier this year, some of the crew

1611.46.text: grew a softball-sized ball of water floating in space

1614.69.text: and nudged a compact video camera

1616.89.text: encased in a waterproof housing into the middle of it.

1619.89.text: They also broke out the station's 3-D camera

1623.89.text: When they sent the images back home,

1626.00.text: our television crew edited the footage

1628.17.text: and posted both a 3-D version and a regular version

1633.40.text: In a little over two months,

1635.43.text: this video received more than two million views.

1638.63.text: By the way, that 3-D video camera on station

1641.50.text: is part of a legitimate scientific investigation

1644.56.text: run here at the Marshall Center

1646.33.text: studying why a 3-D video camera in orbit

1648.69.text: does not degrade as fast as a traditional video camera.

1652.59.text: Right now, regular cameras are replaced every 8 to 12 months

1656.17.text: due to the high number of hot or burned-out pixels,

1659.17.text: those little white dots you see is some footage from station.

1663.40.text: A 3-D camera has virtually zero burned-out pixels,

1666.76.text: meaning it can be used a lot longer

1669.00.text: and save on the cost of sending up replacement cameras.

1672.46.text: The team here, led by Rodney Grubbs,

1677.00.text: helping bring back some incredible images

1679.46.text: of our astronauts living and working in space.

1683.00.text: And that will do it for our look back at the year in research

1689.76.text: and follow us on social media

1691.56.text: to learn more about these and other investigations

1694.69.text: as we continue to work off the Earth, for the Earth.
